job_title: Shift Supervisor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Fun job a lot of the time. Over the pandemic we got free food and drinks daily, regardless of if you worked or not. They also match 401k up to 10%
cons: As a shift supervisor at a high volume store I did not make enough money per hour for the amount of responsibility I had. I very much enjoyed the job, but my financial situation definitely took tole on my mental health. Also, customers can be overwhelming at times. Also you pay for the health insurance benefits they brag so hard about.

pros: Good way to get your hands dirty in a career.

pros: Up until October 5th, 2021, baristas could get 1 free drink every day that they weren't working. Now I believe we get 7 free food items per week. Both of these benefits were given to baristas for COVID-19 relief. We also basically get as many free drinks we want during our shift and 30 minutes before and after our shift. During our shift we also get 1 free food item. Minors also are given a half hour break when working shifts over 5 hours. Every barista is given at least 1 10 minute break during their shift. Work clothes are definitely more relaxed than a lot of places. We are allowed to wear jeans, work appropriate sneakers, a variety of tops, and even dresses or skirts! We are allowed to wear leggings too, but only under dresses or skirts. Starbucks also gives partners (that's what employees are called) lots of benefits including free online college through ASU! Another plus is great starting pay.
cons: We do get tips, but all tips we make within a week are split up amongst all partners, so we don't get very much. Although we do have a more relaxed dress code, there are still limitations, such as no nail polish (which is pretty normal in the food industry), we can't wear light or faded jeans, no ripped clothes, no t-shirts (unless they're polo shirts or shirts bought from coffeegear.com), tops have to be a certain color, etc. Basically, we still dress for safety and we are required to wear clothes that match our aprons. Even though we get unlimited free drinks during our shifts, we aren't allowed to drink on the floor, meaning if we want to take a drink, we have to stop what we're doing and go to the back. When working during a rush, you might not even be able to take a break to go to the back to take a drink, which is not to say we are being overworked, we just can't be constantly going to the back just to get a drink.

review_title: Not paid enough for the work you do.
pros: I love the free drinks you get while on shift and all of the baristas I worked with were the nicest people. It was great to make connections with regulars and further my love for coffee and coffee making.
cons: I was so stressed working at starbucks I literally could not sleep at night because I would fear my next shift. I would say 60% of customers in my location were kind and understanding but the rest were awful. I have been spit at, cussed at, harassed, and even hit on/stalked a bit by customers. I got paid 11 bucks an hour and tips were split up BETWEEN EVERYONE based on hours worked. I honestly thought was not fair because people who slacked off or didn't get the tip still got it if that makes sense. My manager was horrible, scheduling was never correct and it was always the partners fault if the manager messed up on shifts. We would have a constant rotation of new people because the conditions were so bad people would just quit and walk off not even give their 2 weeks it was that bad. The district managers would come in and try to "trick us" to see how good we were and then they demanded all this free stuff like they owned the place. I had my district manager come in during rush hour and make us make her 2 fresh coffee travelers and pastries for her kids school meeting. We had a line out the door and she just walked in and demanded that and got mad at us when we couldn't make it fast enough and when I asked how she was going to pay (cash or card) she literally laughed at me and said "oh honey, you must be new, I am the DM and I dont pay for these things. Haha put it on my tab hehe." I didn't get paid enough for the crap I put up with. I put my two weeks in and my manager came up to me on my last few shifts and literally told me I was going to work way past my cap hours and everyday and she didn't ask she just went ahead and scheduled me even when she knew I was quitting. After that I told her I wanted to quit on the spot and she got really petty with me and told me if I walked out I could never work at a Starbucks again even if it was a small one at target/grocery store. After she told me that I said I would finish out my shifts and she immediately told me I was not allowed and I should leave. So she completely disregarded what I said about finishing out my two weeks and banned me from starbucks herself. I had a few coworkers hear this conversation and they told me to report it to corporate. I did nothing was done about it. After I was basically forced to leave not even 3 weeks later every single morning shift partner but 1 quit. Worst experience of my life, really made me dislike the company because they say they care but they don't. I have worked in military environments, rescue and EMS and this silly barista job had me more stressed than any of those.

pros: The pay is technically better than what you can expect at many other retail/ fast food jobs. It is not worth it.
cons:
This was far and away the worst job I have ever worked in my entire career ever. Just know that every single one of my coworkers-- across multiple stores in different states, with different personalities and proficiencies-- hated the job and just about the only thing we ever talked about was how much we hated that job and how we wanted to get out. This job will ravage your body, exhaust your mind and leave you a bitter antisocial husk if you let it. 

I'm leaving this review as a word of caution: unless you are truly at the end of your rope and less than a month away from total financial catastrophe, do not pursue a job at Starbucks. Run away before it's too late. 

I understand that this sounds hyperbolic, but it is exactly how I feel. Listen, I'm out now. I don't have to put up with that job anymore. If you're reading this you still have a chance to avoid it. Please do not work at Starbucks.

Starbucks has incredible benefits like free Spotify, discounts on travel, free coffee mark outs, healthcare, the list goes on. I enjoyed the fast paced environment as I worked near the hospital.
cons: I actually left because I was in a mental health crisis. Considering Starbucks is all about mental health, I thought they would be understanding of my situation. I was actually forced to quit because my leave of absence could not be processed before 2 weeks. In addition to this, Starbucks RARELY gave raises. I started at 9.15/hr and after 2 years I ended with 10.20, only due to covid causing the “biggest raise in history”. I worked myself to death and never got promoted. Im aware most of my problems are due to my specific manager.

review_title: Great Benefits, not so great pay
pros: Do this for the benefits. Their full benefits for part time employees are the best I've seen in any other company. Fully vested 401k from the moment to get them is great, as well as great health insurance, dental, vision AND other mental health support apps (and Spotify!) AND free tuition for college is honestly insanely good.
cons: They will work you the house down, especially in the mornings, especially on weekends. It can be extremely stressful at times, and you have to be QUICK, because they're timing you (at least during peak). Employee turnover makes it really hard to get a stable team to work with, and you're always picking up someone else's slack.

job_title: Full Time Barista in Oakland, CA
pros:
Unlimited free drinks during your shift, and you used to get one free drink + fresh food item a day. However, they have changed this benefit to restrict food items to 7 a week, and you have to mark it out short before, during, or shortly after a shift. Bummer for partners who rely on it to eat, but at least most partners can get something out of it.

Environment is very busy, demanding at times, and fun for those who enjoy the thrill of a huge rush in the food prep or barring department. Depending on your location, partners might be the best people you've ever had the chance to work with. For those who enjoy food service and interacting with customers in general, it is going to be a great time.

It's near impossible to get fired unless you are constantly no-show and not calling it in.

Medical benefits are pretty comprehensive and have saved me tonnes and tonnes since I started working here, which is largely a poor reflection of the US medical system, but nonetheless a great reason to work at Starbucks.
cons:
Management clearly don't care about us and are more interested in keeping their bonuses or accelerating their personal careers. Partners are burnt out and calling out, and burning themselves out by covering for those who call out. Took my location months and months to get proper staffing. We've had managers who were passive aggressive, hardly understanding, and district managers who did not understand the issue and tried to turn it back on us when we reached out to him as a store.

And because it's nearly impossible to get fired, a partner who is hugely disliked and has been toeing the line with sexual harassment and racism is still at our store whilst Ethics and Compliance take the time to sort it out.

Starbucks consistently shuts down unionising efforts and then try to hide it, as is evident with the current situation in Buffalo, NY. Senior Executive Rossann Williams sent out a newsletter to partners that used largely gaslighty language with likely intentions to misinform and to discourage unionising efforts.

Starbucks' values have definitely turned away from its initial intents of being a place for connections to happen between customer and barista. They turned towards, and have completely become, fast food and fast-sugar-providers as UberEats and mobile orders began to dominate and put unrealistic work expectations on baristas. But they still demand the same level of customer connection, which is now completely insignificant and out the door with the way the company culture is turning.

cons:
The second you go over 43 hours a pay period you get a nice talking to by your manager. Overtime is practically forbidden. The social culture of employees is very invasive and clicky, if you get along with your coworkers everything should be fine, but if you don't it'll feel like working in a prison because everyone is working in such close quarters. 
If your Supervisor or Manager ever uses the phrasing "Im just coaching you" it means they don't like your personality and you have to change it. Starbucks is big on micromanaging your personality to match their ideal "Barista" persona. Its ridiculously demoralizing.

pros:
-Good coworkers, including some in management.
-Variety in the work kept it from getting old.
-Customer service skills I learned here have helped me a lot in my current job.
-Benefits are fine, especially PTO, but they're getting more and more standard these days.
cons:
-Pay was too low for the stress everyone felt every day.
-The standard shift was difficult, understaffed, and you could rarely get to all of the cleaning and maintenance tasks you were supposed to do each shift.
-Corporate mindset is that the only thing that can get in the way of continual growth and increased efficiency is the attitude and demeanor of employees. 90% of all shifts were understaffed, often severely, even when everyone knew that the scheduling was insufficient.
-If I had to sum up the corporate culture in one phrase, it might be 'bait and switch.' We were constantly told that once the labor system caught up with our sales, we would start getting more labor and shifts wouldn't be so horrible. This kind of communication happened for all of the 7 years I worked here- things are always just about to get better, but it's always out of management's hands.
-The way people are promoted is also pretty BS. At some stores, all you need to become a shift are to work full time for a year and want it. At others, people that are very well qualified can't move up no matter how hard they try. I was a shift for 6 out of my 7 years, and although I wanted to become an Assistant Store Manager, I kept getting the run around about what I should do to make it happen. My District Manager literally said he had no say over who could be promoted, that it was decided basically by how much 'positive buzz' someone could get in the district. In order to help build my 'story,' I was volun-told to help open a new store as one of their supervisors, and actually I had more experience at the company than almost everyone else there, including the manager. Turns out she disliked me (later I heard someone from another store say, 'Oh, XXX is your new manager? Well if you aren't gay she won't like you,' and I'd say that seems accurate). Instead of moving up, we eventually had a conversation where she laid out a vague ultimatum, then said we would reassess whether this job was a good fit for me. After 7 years... So I quit.
-Quality of your experience varies wildly between stores. The store I was at for most of my career was well run, had a great client base, and was still very understaffed. I also worked at stores where everyday was an 'every man for himself' kind of experience, and there was no time for coaching or any kind of improvement. If you handed out a crap drink or poured 3-hr old coffee, you just crossed your self and sent them on their way.
-While supervisors and baristas are getting pulverized on the floor, management spends over half their time in meetings, talking about their feelings, and working towards self-improvement. I'm not even joking. Store managers have become more and more a back-of-house only position, and when you went back there, most of the time they were in a meeting talking about their feelings. Not saying there isn't a place for that, but not when the rest of the store is drowning and can't get caught up on orders.
-Although the company culture sounds good- basically it's about making people's day with small moments, making connections, working to always improve, that kinda thing- it's completely subverted by the actual experience of employees. During my fiance's last week, there were dozens of customers who she had been close to for 5 years, and yet she was too overwhelmed and busy that whole time to even tell them she had quit.
-The upshot of all of this is that the company is losing a lot of it's talent and experience. I worked there for 7 years, my fiance for 6, and we both know several experienced baristas that have left within the last year because of how poorly run everything is. If you notice that quality seems to have gone down, wait times have gone up, and mobile order never seems to work any more, that's why. Stores are understaffed all the time because of their mindset of endless growth, and as a result, turnover just gets worse and worse. New baristas start, work for a few months, realize how terrible it is, and quit and get replaced. It's just not a responsible or tenable way to run a company.

review_title: Great Coworkers, But Sadly Overall Terrible Management
pros:
-Great people to work with overall amongst baristas and supervisors
-Some good managers, though few and far between
-IF you decide you really love retail, this company could potentially be a good place to gain management experience
-As a resume padder, saying you worked for Starbucks can make recruiters involved in people facing professions more likely to pay attention to you (think beyond retail, this extends to many careers). The company has a very positive reputation amongst others so if you can prove to your future employers what made working at Starbucks turn you into an customer service expert, excellent communicator, and team player, you will likely gain people's positive attention
-Their benefits can be pretty good when used strategically
-Flexible scheduling is probably their biggest selling point, though they aren't as flexible as they often claim
cons:
I met fantastic friends and people here over the years, but sadly, due to the issues I will list below that continue to seem to worsen, I left for better opportunities and now work for a company that treats me far better, pays me far better, and that I am far happier at. I wish all my fellow baristas and future baristas the best in whatever they choose to do in life. 

However, at this time, I simply can't recommend this company as anything other than a short-term stepping stone, and, with how competitive other companies are becoming with regards to pay and compensation, I don't even know if I can recommend it for that anymore. 

Cons are as follows:
-Obsessed with customer metrics and scoring, public image as being this idyllic company to work for, bottom line
-Laughably low pay for the industry at this point
-Overworked, understaffed, low morale, and admin refuses to admit it's a problem, or when they do they don't actually do anything to fix it (and this was before the labor shortage that is now being exacerbated by the pandemic)
-Toxic management is generally the rule, not the exception
-Admin is actively targeting unionization efforts
-Admin is insanely obsessed with their manicured PR image, at the cost of employee health
-An extremely entitled customer base at this point, that is further enabled by upper management with little actual care for how it impacts employee health, bottom line is that if a customer will produce money for the store, very little will stop the store from taking their business, even if their demands are unreasonable. This doesn't hurt the managers of course, it all hits the frontline employee, who is left as an afterthought.
-Massive logistical issues with controlling mobile orders and regulating drive-thrus, which have thrown many stores into perpetual chaos.

review_title: I learnt a lot and enjoyed the job but it had its pros and cons…
pros: Great educational opportunities within the company. There is room to grow and progress with them. Benefits are okay with free everyday and once a week. If you stay with the company a long time earning bean stock is a great extra. Staff overall were lovely to work with and shops are very self efficient.
cons: Can be very hard work and long days. If you have staff that don’t care the work load becomes a lot to manage. The 50% discount on shift for food at the prices they charge is costing a lot of money that you earn going back to the company that pays you is pretty depressing and means staff try to avoid eating at the shop. When your working a 13 hour shift you have no choice but to spend money in the shop you work. Not a lot of support as a barista. When you train and work towards management levels there is minimal to no recognition. I worked as a ‘lead supervisor’ which meant nothing within the company but meant my responsibilities were to bs an assistant manager with out the title or the pay. When my manager left I ran the shop alone for money travelling hours to help my team and I barely got a thank you from the area manager when I left and they tried to fire me for running 5 minutes late when I was running a shop for them and travelling five hours a day and covering all sickness myself because we was understaffed some days I was out the house 19 hours for work and would get up after a couple hours sleep and do it again and got no appreciation from the company. Obviously if I didn’t care about my shop, my team and my staff I wouldn’t have bothered.

review_title: For a Starbucks Inside a Target Store
pros:
Many of the barista duties were simple to learn.
There were plenty of things to do that kept me busy.
Helping out customers.
Some nice coworkers.
Polite repeat customers.
cons:
For the particular franchise I worked at, the manager did not give us our schedules electronically (i.e. by email), so we had to use our phones to take a picture of said schedules. Very unreliable and INCONVENIENT.

Since this franchise was located in a Target store, we were not allowed to accept tips.

The manager was strict about how we communicated with customers. We were supposed to say "Thank You" to the customer at the end of every interaction. Was chewed out for saying "You're welcome", "Anytime", and "No problem" to the customers.

Since a good part of the small staff had previously worked at other Starbucks locations before, the manager expected us to know how to do everything in a short amount of time. It's all doable of course, but it can be a bit intimidating for a part-time worker with no previous barista experience. And in addition, expect to be working with only 1 other employee at a given shift.

Some of the staff, including the manager, were passive aggressive and toxic.

*1. Easy to get dates with other hot baristas or some fine looking customers.

3. 1lbs of coffee or a box of tea free every week 
4. Starbucks stocks accumulate with hours worked
5. Smoking trees in the back store when the shift is done... good times.

I guess not everyone will have the same experience but I'm here to tell you.. yes you. You young individual seeking supplemental income while figuring out where your education is going to take you in this world. You can bang hot baristas and clients while lit on a free caffeine high all the while your bank account fills up and you finish your studies. Work doesn't have to be hard.. only your hot dog... I don't even know where I'm going with this... stay true homies
